Triggering Event: He woke up suddenly, heart pounding, gasping for breath. The clock read 3:05 AM. His partner stirred beside him but didn't wake. He rushed to the bathroom, leaning heavily against the sink as waves of dizziness hit him. The mirror reflected a pale face, beads of sweat trickling down his temples. He couldn't shake off the feeling that something was horribly wrong.
Generated Assessment: This is ridiculous. Why can't I just have one fucking night's sleep? It's not like I'm constantly lying awake at 3 AM worrying about something stupid. Everyone else has normal lives; they don't spend all night freaking out over nothing. Even my parents, who are always complaining about how much work they have, never lie awake at 2:30 AM, worried sick. They're so calm and collected during the day, and I'm the one who has to stay up late, stressing because of some minor anxiety attack. It feels unfair compared to them. It's not like I'm trying to be perfect. I've been doing well this year, financially and academically, despite everything going on. But no matter how hard I try, I still end up getting anxious about everything—work, school, relationships, even my own health. My friends and family act like it's no big deal, but they don't know what it's like to live with these constant worries. I feel like I'm missing out on life because I'm stuck in my head, worrying about things that might never happen. And yet, when I look around, everyone else seems to have it easier. They get to go to bed early, while I'm still lying awake, thinking about all the things that could go wrong tomorrow. It doesn’t help that my partner’s anxiety problems make me feel like an asshole for having any worries at all. I mean, why bother when you can

A wave of stress surged through her as she realized this meant another late night working on a backup system and another weekend spent away from her children.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her empty classroom after hours, she finds a crumpled note left on her desk: "You're ruining my life." Her heart aches as she recognizes the handwriting of a former student who's been struggling. She feels the weight of his pain, and her own loneliness, pressing down like a heavy stone.

This experience has made her realize that sometimes people feel trapped by their circumstances. Triggering Event: At 6 PM, he finds his wife's packed suitcase by the front door.
Generated Assessment: It’s never gonna work. She’s always been this way. When she goes out of town for work, she leaves me to deal with everything by myself. I feel so alone and exhausted every time she does it. It just makes me realize that we’re not meant to be together. Maybe I’m just too much to handle. I don’t know how many times I’ve tried to talk about my feelings, but nothing ever changes. Every single time I tell her how I feel, she gets defensive and tells me that I need to calm down. Like, what am I even supposed to calm down from? Feeling ignored, unheard, and left behind? Does she really think that just because I say something, I want to fight? I can barely stand up straight when I’m feeling overwhelmed. And then she has the nerve to tell me I need to chill out? She doesn’t care enough to listen. Triggering Event: A man in his late twenties, dressed in his now-familiar black uniform, was restocking the shelves at midnight when he noticed a familiar bottle of perfume. It had been her favorite. As he reached out to place it among its peers, he paused, remembering how she'd insisted on wearing it even after the chemo made her sensitive to strong scents. His grip tightened around the bottle until his knuckles turned white. He'd heard whispers that her former friend was now dating someone new, laughing and moving on as if nothing had happened. The man's breath caught in his throat, a familiar anger boiling up inside him. He put the perfume back with a force that rattled the other bottles, then strode to the stockroom, his heart pounding with vengeance.

Triggering Event: At 6 PM, in his bustling restaurant's kitchen, he was preparing for the evening rush. A young sous-chef loudly corrected him on a recipe they'd discussed privately earlier that day. The chef felt his face grow hot as murmurs filled the room; he couldn't remember the last time he'd felt so humiliated.

I fucking well know how to make that sauce from scratch. If anything, I've perfected it over the years, and it's supposed to be a staple here at the restaurant. Still, he had no right to be so loud, especially since we were already short-staffed. What the fuck was he thinking? And another thing, why did everyone have to hear that? The entire kitchen fell silent, and I could feel eyes on me. I didn't even get a chance to respond before the door swung open again, and some new line cook rushed in with a bunch of dishes. Triggering Event: While debugging her latest code, she felt an abrupt heat rise in her chest. Her fingers froze over the keyboard as the lines of code began to blur. The familiar hum of her home office suddenly sounded like a cacophony, each beep and whirr echoing through her skull. She tried to take a deep breath but felt only tightness, her heart pounding against her ribs like a trapped animal. "Not now," she whispered, her hands trembling as she reached for the panic button on her desk.

Does she really believe I'd just sit here with my head in my hands, feeling like a lunatic, while she's working away? **Doesn't she realize that I can see what she's doing?** Can't she understand that we're both in this together? That we need to work together if we want to make this project work? Why does she have to act so calm when I feel like I'm about to burst? "I mean, come on! You know exactly how I feel. We've been at each other's throats all day, and now she's acting like everything is fine. **Is she pretending not to notice how much stress I'm under?** Doesn't she care that I'm barely holding myself together here? And yet, she's just typing away like nothing's happening. **Does she think I don't hear every keystroke?** Do I sound crazy saying things like this?
